Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Rapid Design and Prototyping System for Lab-On-Chip Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to reduce cost and increase accuracy of solutions for the healthcare industry, including point-of-care diagnostics, therapeutics, and drug development, by enabling new lab-on-chip technologies. These technologies rely on microfluidic devices, small plastic parts that automatically and efficiently conduct scientific experiments with tiny volumes of liquid samples. Point-of-care devices can have a particularly profound impact on underserved communities by allowing access to testing otherwise unavailable due to cost and resource issues. The proposed system will decrease the time and expense required to develop technologies addressing these challenges.

This SBIR Phase I project addresses the speed of lab-on-chip development through three main technical innovations: 1) A library of microfluidic features for design of microfluidic parts; 2) A rapid tooling system rapidly producing microfluidic molds; and 3) The macro-to-micro interface where lab-on-chip devices connect to the outside world. The proposed project will create an automated system to quickly and reliably connectorize microfluidic devices, increasing reliability and ease of use. The performance goal is a complete lab-on-chip prototyping system providing fully functional devices in less than a week.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A key problem in the microfluidic industry is the inability to quickly source prototype devices that are representative of high volume production processes. This research built an integrated system consisting of three main components to allow users to rapidly design, quote, and produce microfluidic devices. The first major component is an automated prototyping system that will allow for the physical production of thermoplastic microfluidic devices. The work combines rapid micromachining, hot embossing, thermal diffusion bonding, and a proprietary method to rapidly and precisely bond modular components to a prototype microfluidic device. All of these technologies are controlled by a centralized system that automatically tracks production data throughout the prototyping process. The result allows us to produce functional thermoplastic microfluidic prototypes in as little as two days. This outcome is a drastic improvement over existing techniques that require weeks for prototype production at extremely high costs.

Another major focus of the research was to create a modular component library that researchers can use to solve common microfluidic problems. In early customer research we determined that the connection between thermoplastic microfluidic devices and external instrumentation is a known challenge in the industry. We developed three different tubing connectors that are compatible with our prototyping system to solve this problem. Users can simply indicate a through-hole on their device design in the correct connector location, and we can use the automated prototyping system to quickly and permanently attach connectors in a contaminant and leak-free manner. While we have only developed the tubing connectors so far, this technology has laid the foundation for the integration of many other modular components such as valves, pumps, reagent storage, sensors, and many more.

We also created a web application in this work to serve as the link between users and the other aspects of our system. The web application allows researchers to quickly and easily upload prototype device designs, receive quotes with integrated manufacturing feedback, and dynamically select components from the automated library for production in their chosen design. In addition, the web application is linked directly to our automated prototyping system in a way that allows us to seamlessly pull design information such as component positions and geometry into our prototyping system, while constantly tracking data collected during the production process for each device. 

The combination of these three areas of focus has created a new approach to microfluidic device prototyping that could make microfluidics faster to develop, cheaper, and more accessible to a wide variety of researchers. Hopefully, the technologies developed in this work will allow more applications to transition from the lab to commercial success, ultimately helping to make people around the world healthier.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/20/2021
Modified by: Joshua Gomes
